items.title: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba resigns after election defeats
items.standfirst: The prime minister had struggled to inspire confidence as Japan faced economic headwinds.
items.content: The prime minister had struggled to inspire confidence as Japan faced economic headwinds.

items.title: Japan PM Ishiba says he will step down to take blame for July election rout
items.standfirst: TOKYO -- Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba on Sunday said that he will step down to take responsibility for the rout of the ruling coalition in the July 20 upper house election, just 11 months after assuming the post, having struggled to navigate the sluggish economy amid persistently high…
items.content: TOKYO -- Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba on Sunday said that he will step down to take responsibility for the rout of the ruling coalition in the July 20 upper house election, just 11 months after assuming the post, having struggled to navigate the sluggish economy amid persistently high…

items.title: Japan PM Shigeru Ishiba to resign amid fallout from disastrous elections
items.standfirst: Public broadcaster says prime minister has made decision to avoid divide within his Liberal Democratic partyJapan’s prime minister, Shigeru Ishiba, is to resign less than a year after taking office, throwing the country’s politics into turmoil and setting in motion a potentially messy contest to replace him as leader of the ruling Liberal Democratic party (LDP).The softly spoken centrist has presided over two disastrous elections since being elected to lead the LDP last autumn. In October, the party and its junior coalition partner Komeito lost their majority in the lower house and met the same fate in upper house elections this July. Continue reading...
items.content: Public broadcaster says prime minister has made decision to avoid divide within his Liberal Democratic partyJapan’s prime minister, Shigeru Ishiba, is to resign less than a year after taking office, throwing the country’s politics into turmoil and setting in motion a potentially messy contest to replace him as leader of the ruling Liberal Democratic party (LDP).The softly spoken centrist has presided over two disastrous elections since being elected to lead the LDP last autumn. In October, the party and its junior coalition partner Komeito lost their majority in the lower house and met the same fate in upper house elections this July. Continue reading...

items.title: Japan Prime Minister Ishiba Shigeru announces his resignation
items.standfirst: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba announced Sunday he will step down from his post after weeks of mounting pressure for his resignation. Ishiba had faced calls for his resignation in recent weeks after the ruling Liberal Democratic Party failed to secure a majority in the lower house election…

items.title: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba to resign
items.standfirst: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has expressed his intention on Sunday to step down following growing calls from his party to take responsibility for a historic defeat in July's parliamentary election.
items.content: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has expressed his intention on Sunday to step down following growing calls from his party to take responsibility for a historic defeat in July's parliamentary election.(Image credit: Philip Fong)

items.title: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba to step down
items.standfirst: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has decided to resign to avoid a split within the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, public broadcaster NHK said on Sunday.
items.content: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has decided to resign to avoid a split within the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, public broadcaster NHK said on Sunday.

items.title: Embattled Japanese PM Shigeru Ishiba to resign, media report
items.standfirst: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has decided to step down, local media reported on Sunday, as members of his ruling party seek to hold a new leadership race following disastrous upper house elections. James Simms, a freelance journalist based in Tokyo reports on the political crisis.
items.content: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has decided to step down, local media reported on Sunday, as members of his ruling party seek to hold a new leadership race following disastrous upper house elections. His resignation opens the way for a presidential race within the party.

items.content: Ukraine's air force reported a record number of drones and missiles were launched by Russia in the latest nightly attack.

items.title: Ukraine's Main Government Building Hit for First Time in Russian Attack
items.standfirst: "For the first time, the government building was damaged by an enemy attack, including the roof and upper floors," Ukrainian Prime Minister Yulia Svyrydenko said.
items.content: "For the first time, the government building was damaged by an enemy attack, including the roof and upper floors," Ukrainian Prime Minister Yulia Svyrydenko said.

items.title: Zelensky: Russia launched 800 drones overnight
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky stated on Sunday that Russia launched 800 drones and 13 missiles, four of them ballistic, on his country overnight, including some set off from Belarus.Writing o...
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky stated on Sunday that Russia launched 800 drones and 13 missiles, four of them ballistic, on his country overnight, including some set off from Belarus.Writing o...

items.title: Watch: BBC at the scene of Ukrainian government building strike
items.standfirst: One of Kyiv's main government buildings was hit in overnight missile and drone strikes by Russia.
items.content: One of Kyiv's main government buildings was hit in overnight missile and drone strikes by Russia.

items.title: Russia conducts massive air attack on Kyiv, other Ukrainian regions
items.standfirst: Russia hit Kyiv and other parts of Ukraine with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since its full-scale invasion, killing at least four people and setting the seat of the Ukrainian government in the capital ablaze. France 24's Gulliver Cragg reports from Kyiv.
items.content: Russia hit Kyiv and other parts of Ukraine with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since its full-scale invasion, killing at least four people and setting the seat of the Ukrainian government in the capital ablaze. France 24's Gulliver Cragg reports from Kyiv.

items.title: Russia assaults Ukraine with over 800 drones and decoys, the largest such attack in the war
items.standfirst: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began.
items.content: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began.(Image credit: Evgeniy Maloletka)

items.title: Ukraine’s main government building ablaze in massive Russian air attack
items.standfirst: An infant was among two people killed in a Russian drone and missile attack on Kyiv that set fire to scores of buildings in the capital, including the main government building, Ukrainian officials said Sunday. At least four people were killed and dozens wounded across Ukraine as Russia launched more than 800 drones and 13 missiles in overnight attacks, Ukraine’s air force added.
items.content: An infant was among two people killed in a Russian drone and missile attack on Kyiv that set fire to scores of buildings in the capital, including the main government building, Ukrainian officials said Sunday. At least four people were killed and dozens wounded across Ukraine as Russia launched more than 800 drones and 13 missiles in overnight attacks, Ukraine’s air force added.

items.title: Largest Russian air attack of war sets fire to Ukrainian cabinet building and kills three including child
items.standfirst: Unclear if fire at main Ukrainian government building the result of a direct strike or falling debrisRussia’s largest overnight air attack of the war has set the main building of the Ukrainian government in Kyiv on fire and left three people dead, including an infant, Ukrainian officials said on Sunday.Russia hit Ukraine’s capital with drones and missiles, injuring 18 people and setting scores of buildings on fire, including . Continue reading...
items.content: Unclear if fire at main Ukrainian government building the result of a direct strike or falling debrisRussia’s largest overnight air attack of the war has set the main building of the Ukrainian government in Kyiv on fire and left three people dead, including an infant, Ukrainian officials said on Sunday.Russia hit Ukraine’s capital with drones and missiles, injuring 18 people and setting scores of buildings on fire, including . Continue reading...

ai_summary: Russia launched a record number of drones and missiles overnight.
The attack damaged the main government building in Kyiv.
President Zelensky reported 800 drones and 13 missiles were launched.
The attack killed at least four people in Kyiv and other regions.
The attack was the largest aerial assault since the war began.

clusters.title: Carlo Acutis, ‘God’s influencer’ who died aged 15, declared a saint by Pope Leo
clusters.neutral_headline: Teen gamer who 'performed miracles' becomes first millennial saint

items.title: Carlo Acutis, ‘God’s influencer’ who died aged 15, declared a saint by Pope Leo
items.standfirst: London-born Italian, who died in 2006, built websites to spread Catholic teaching and is credited with two miraclesPope Leo XIV has declared the London-born Italian Carlo Acutis, who died in 2006 age 15, the Catholic church’s first millennial saint during an open-air mass in a packed St Peter’s Square.Carlo, who died of leukaemia, built websites to spread Catholic teaching, earning him the nickname “God’s influencer”. He was canonised alongside Pier Giorgio Frassati, another young Catholic activist, who died a century ago. Continue reading...
items.content: London-born Italian, who died in 2006, built websites to spread Catholic teaching and is credited with two miraclesPope Leo XIV has declared the London-born Italian Carlo Acutis, who died in 2006 age 15, the Catholic church’s first millennial saint during an open-air mass in a packed St Peter’s Square.Carlo, who died of leukaemia, built websites to spread Catholic teaching, earning him the nickname “God’s influencer”. He was canonised alongside Pier Giorgio Frassati, another young Catholic activist, who died a century ago. Continue reading...

items.title: Pope Leo declares Italian teen computer whiz a saint
items.standfirst: Carlo Acutis, who who died of leukaemia aged 15, became the first Catholic saint of the millennial generation on Sunday, in a Vatican ceremony led by Pope Leo and attended by thousands of young worshippers. The pope also canonised another popular Italian figure who died young, Pier Giorgio Frassati.
items.content: Carlo Acutis, who who died of leukaemia aged 15, became the first Catholic saint of the millennial generation on Sunday, in a Vatican ceremony led by Pope Leo and attended by thousands of young worshippers. The pope also canonised another popular Italian figure who died young, Pier Giorgio Frassati.

items.title: Pope Leo canonizes 'God's influencer,' the Catholic Church's first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Pope Leo XIV declared 15-year-old Carlo Acutis the first millennial saint at an open-air mass attended by tens of thousands of people in St Peter's Square outside the Vatican on Sunday.
items.content: Pope Leo XIV declared 15-year-old Carlo Acutis the first millennial saint at an open-air mass attended by tens of thousands of people in St Peter's Square outside the Vatican on Sunday.

items.title: Teen gamer who 'performed miracles' becomes first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Before his death at 15, Carlo Acutis was known for his love of technology and had created a website to document miracles.
items.content: Before his death at 15, Carlo Acutis was known for his love of technology and had created a website to document miracles.

items.title: A teen nicknamed 'God's influencer' is becoming the first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Carlo Acutis, who died of leukemia at 15 in 2006, is known in the Catholic Church as "God's influencer" for harnessing technology to spread the word about miracles.
items.content: Carlo Acutis, who died of leukemia at 15 in 2006, is known in the Catholic Church as "God's influencer" for harnessing technology to spread the word about miracles.(Image credit: Valerio Muscella for NPR)

items.title: They called him 'God's influencer,' the Catholic Church canonizes the first millennial saint
items.standfirst: The Catholic Church is about to canonize its first saint of the millennial generation.
items.content: The Catholic Church is about to canonize its first saint of the millennial generation.

items.title: Teen known as "God's Influencer" about to become first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Dressed in jeans, Nike sneakers and a sweatshirt, with his hands clasped around a rosary, Carlo Acutis has generated near rock star-like fame among young Catholics.
items.content: Dressed in jeans, Nike sneakers and a sweatshirt, with his hands clasped around a rosary, Carlo Acutis has generated near rock star-like fame among young Catholics.

items.title: Teen known as 'God's influencer' to become the first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Known as 'God's influencer' Carlo Acutis will become the first millennial saint at a solemn canonization Mass held by Pope Leo XIV.
items.content: Known as 'God's influencer' Carlo Acutis will become the first millennial saint at a solemn canonization Mass held by Pope Leo XIV.

ai_summary: Carlo Acutis, who died at 15, is the first millennial saint.
He was known as "God's influencer" for using technology.
Acutis created a website to document miracles.
He died of leukemia in 2006.
Pope Leo XIV led the canonization ceremony.

clusters.title: 300 South Koreans detained at Hyundai plant in US to be released, says Seoul
clusters.neutral_headline: South Korea Concludes Talks With US to Release Citizens Held

items.title: 300 South Koreans detained at Hyundai plant in US to be released, says Seoul
items.standfirst: Footage of raid by US immigration officials showed detained workers in handcuffs and with chains around their anklesSouth Korea has said negotiations with the US to secure the release of its nationals detained in a raid by US immigration officials on a Hyundai plant in the state of Georgia have been “concluded” and that they would soon be freed and flown home.It follows the arrest of more than 300 South Korean workers at a Hyundai-LG battery site being built in the southern US on Thursday. Continue reading...
items.content: Footage of raid by US immigration officials showed detained workers in handcuffs and with chains around their anklesSouth Korea has said negotiations with the US to secure the release of its nationals detained in a raid by US immigration officials on a Hyundai plant in the state of Georgia have been “concluded” and that they would soon be freed and flown home.It follows the arrest of more than 300 South Korean workers at a Hyundai-LG battery site being built in the southern US on Thursday. Continue reading...

items.title: South Korea Issues Update on Georgia Hyundai Plant ICE Raid
items.standfirst: South Korea has reached a deal to bring home its citizens detained in Thursday's massive immigration raid on a factory construction site, the government said.
items.content: South Korea has reached a deal to bring home its citizens detained in Thursday's massive immigration raid on a factory construction site, the government said.

items.title: Korea Concludes Talks With US to Release Citizens Held: Yonhap
South Korea concludes talks to release nationals detained in Hyundai raid in US
items.standfirst: US officials say the workers - including more than 300 South Koreans - were working illegally.
items.content: US officials say the workers - including more than 300 South Koreans - were working illegally.

items.title: South Korea vows 'all-out efforts' to help hundreds detained in Hyundai raid
items.standfirst: South Korean President Lee Jae-myung ordered all out efforts to respond to the arrests of its citizens in an immigration raid on a Hyundai facility in Georgia.
items.content: South Korean President Lee Jae-myung ordered all out efforts to respond to the arrests of its citizens in an immigration raid on a Hyundai facility in Georgia.

items.title: Seoul promises to help hundreds of Korean workers arrested in US in Ice raid
items.standfirst: Total of 475 detained in Georgia at construction site of factory to make batteries for Hyundai and Kia carsSouth Korea’s president, Lee Jae Myung, has ordered “all-out efforts” to respond to the arrest of hundreds of its citizens by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) during a raid at a factory being built in Georgia to manufacture car batteries.Cho Hyun, the foreign minister, said the government had set up a taskforce following the arrest of 300 South Korean nationals. Continue reading...
items.content: Total of 475 detained in Georgia at construction site of factory to make batteries for Hyundai and Kia carsSouth Korea’s president, Lee Jae Myung, has ordered “all-out efforts” to respond to the arrest of hundreds of its citizens by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) during a raid at a factory being built in Georgia to manufacture car batteries.Cho Hyun, the foreign minister, said the government had set up a taskforce following the arrest of 300 South Korean nationals. Continue reading...

ai_summary: South Korea reached a deal to release citizens detained in a Hyundai raid.
Over 300 South Korean workers were detained at a Hyundai plant.
The raid was conducted by US immigration officials in Georgia.
The government set up a taskforce after the arrests.
President Lee Jae-myung ordered efforts to help the detained citizens.

clusters.title: Israel intensifies its assault on Gaza City, urging residents to flee
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel orders evacuation of Gaza City as Trump says U.S. in 'deep negotiations' with Hamas

items.title: Israel intensifies its assault on Gaza City, urging residents to flee
items.standfirst: The Israeli army issued evacuation orders and targeted high-rise buildings in Gaza City on Saturday, urging Palestinians to flee south ahead of an escalating offensive to seize the city of nearly 1 million. FRANCE 24's correspondent in Jerusalem, Noga Tarnopolsky, reports.
items.content: The Israeli army issued evacuation orders and targeted high-rise buildings in Gaza City on Saturday, urging Palestinians to flee south ahead of an escalating offensive to seize the city of nearly 1 million. FRANCE 24's correspondent in Jerusalem, Noga Tarnopolsky, reports.

items.title: Israel expands Gaza City operations; residents told to move to safe zone
items.standfirst: Israel's army has urged Palestinians in Gaza City to move to a designated humanitarian area in the south. Meanwhile, an ailing Palestinian toddler recovers in Italy.
items.content: Israel's army has urged Palestinians in Gaza City to move to a designated humanitarian area in the south. Meanwhile, an ailing Palestinian toddler recovers in Italy.

items.title: Israel warns Gaza City residents to evacuate as it prepares assault
items.standfirst: Israel has urged the residents of Gaza City to evacuate as it prepares for a full-scale military assault. Leaflets dropped from the sky telling residents of the famine-stricken area to leave. Haley Ott reports.
items.content: Israel has urged the residents of Gaza City to evacuate as it prepares for a full-scale military assault. Leaflets dropped from the sky telling residents of the famine-stricken area to leave. Haley Ott reports.

items.title: Israel destroys second high-rise as assault on Gaza City intensifies
items.standfirst: Israel continues to expand its military operation in Gaza, urging Palestinians to leave Gaza City and move south.
items.content: Israel continues to expand its military operation in Gaza, urging Palestinians to leave Gaza City and move south.

items.title: Israel orders evacuation of Gaza City as Trump says U.S. in 'deep negotiations' with Hamas
items.standfirst: The Israeli military has ordered residents of Gaza City to evacuate to a designated “humanitarian zone” as its forces intensify a major offensive.
items.content: The Israeli military has ordered residents of Gaza City to evacuate to a designated “humanitarian zone” as its forces intensify a major offensive.

items.title: Israel warns Gaza City residents to flee to 'humanitarian area' - as another tower is bombed
items.standfirst: Any remaining residents in Gaza's largest city should leave for a designated area in the south, Israel's military warned, before bombing a high-rise tower.
items.content: Any remaining residents in Gaza's largest city should leave for a designated area in the south, Israel's military warned, before bombing a high-rise tower.

ai_summary: Israel intensified its assault on Gaza City.
Residents of Gaza City were urged to evacuate south.
Israel targeted high-rise buildings in Gaza City.
The Israeli military ordered residents to move to a "humanitarian zone".
Trump stated the US was in "deep negotiations" with Hamas.

clusters.title: Sabalenka retains US Open title with straight-sets win over Anisimova
clusters.neutral_headline: Sabalenka Wins Second Consecutive US Open, Defeats Anisimova in Final

items.title: Sabalenka retains US Open title with straight-sets win over Anisimova
items.standfirst: Aryna Sabalenka sealed back-to-back titles at Flushing Meadows by seeing off Amanda Anisimova in straight sets (6-3, 7-6) on Saturday evening. Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz, meanwhile, are preparing to face off in a Grand Slam final for the third time this season on Sunday.
items.content: Aryna Sabalenka sealed back-to-back titles at Flushing Meadows by seeing off Amanda Anisimova in straight sets (6-3, 7-6) on Saturday evening. Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz, meanwhile, are preparing to face off in a Grand Slam final for the third time this season on Sunday.

items.title: Aryna Sabalenka defeats Amanda Anisimova for her 2nd consecutive US Open title and 4th at a major
Sabalenka Wins Second Consecutive US Open, Defeats Anisimova in Final
items.standfirst: The No. 1 seed from Belarus became the first woman to win consecutive U.S. Open titles since Serena Williams' three-year streak from 2012-2014.
items.content: The No. 1 seed from Belarus became the first woman to win consecutive U.S. Open titles since Serena Williams' three-year streak from 2012-2014.

items.title: US Open: Sabalenka wins second straight title, defeats Anisimova
items.standfirst: World number one Aryna Sabalenka defended her US Open title with a straight-sets victory against Amanda Anisimova.
items.content: World number one Aryna Sabalenka defended her US Open title with a straight-sets victory against Amanda Anisimova.

items.title: Aryna Sabalenka defeats Amanda Anisimova, winning U.S. Open women's final
items.standfirst: Aryna Sabalenka has won her fourth Grand Slam title overall and second straight at the U.S. Open after defeating Amanda Anisimova on Saturday.
items.content: Aryna Sabalenka has won her fourth Grand Slam title overall and second straight at the U.S. Open after defeating Amanda Anisimova on Saturday.

items.title: Aryna Sabalenka overtakes American Amanda Anisimova to win U.S. Open women's title
items.standfirst: Aryna Sabalenka has done it again. The world's number one women's tennis player defeated American Amanda Anisimova, 6-3, 7-6, to become the first back-to-back U.S. Open winner since Serena Williams.
items.content: Aryna Sabalenka has done it again. The world's number one women's tennis player defeated American Amanda Anisimova, 6-3, 7-6, to become the first back-to-back U.S. Open winner since Serena Williams.

ai_summary: Aryna Sabalenka won her second consecutive US Open title.
She defeated Amanda Anisimova in straight sets.
Sabalenka is the first woman to win consecutive titles since Serena Williams.
This is Sabalenka's fourth Grand Slam title overall.
The final score was 6-3, 7-6.

clusters.title: US independent director Jim Jarmusch beats Gaza war film to Venice top prize
clusters.neutral_headline: Jim Jarmusch’s 'Father Mother Sister Brother' wins Golden Lion at Venice Film Festival

items.title: US independent director Jim Jarmusch beats Gaza war film to Venice top prize
items.standfirst: U.S. indie director Jim Jarmusch unexpectedly won the coveted Golden Lion at the Venice Film Festival on Saturday with "Father Mother Sister Brother", a three-part meditation on the uneasy ties between parents and their adult children. Story by Liza Kaminov.
items.content: U.S. indie director Jim Jarmusch unexpectedly won the coveted Golden Lion at the Venice Film Festival on Saturday with "Father Mother Sister Brother", a three-part meditation on the uneasy ties between parents and their adult children. Story by Liza Kaminov.

items.title: Gaza war film The Voice of Hind Rajab wins 2nd prize at Venice festival
items.standfirst: Director Ben Hania pays tribute to slain five-year old Palestinian girl, calls for accountability for Israeli killings.
items.content: Director Ben Hania pays tribute to slain five-year old Palestinian girl, calls for accountability for Israeli killings.

items.title: Jim Jarmusch’s Father Mother Sister Brother, starring Cate Blanchett, surprise winner of Venice Golden Lion
items.standfirst: The Voice of Hind Rajab, a harrowing account of a Palestinian child’s death in Gaza, won the runner-up Silver LionUS indie director Jim Jarmusch unexpectedly won the coveted Golden Lion at the Venice film festival on Saturday with Father Mother Sister Brother, a three-part meditation on the uneasy tie between parents and their adult children.Although his gentle comedy received largely positive reviews, it had not been a favourite for the top prize, with many critics instead tipping the Voice of Hind Rajab, a harrowing true-life account of the killing of a five-year-old Palestinian girl during the Gaza war. In the end, the film directed by Tunisia’s Kaouther Ben Hania took the runner-up Silver Lion. Continue reading...
items.content: The Voice of Hind Rajab, a harrowing account of a Palestinian child’s death in Gaza, won the runner-up Silver LionUS indie director Jim Jarmusch unexpectedly won the coveted Golden Lion at the Venice film festival on Saturday with Father Mother Sister Brother, a three-part meditation on the uneasy tie between parents and their adult children.Although his gentle comedy received largely positive reviews, it had not been a favourite for the top prize, with many critics instead tipping the Voice of Hind Rajab, a harrowing true-life account of the killing of a five-year-old Palestinian girl during the Gaza war. In the end, the film directed by Tunisia’s Kaouther Ben Hania took the runner-up Silver Lion. Continue reading...

items.title: Jim Jarmusch's 'Father Mother Sister Brother' wins top prize at Venice Film Festival
items.standfirst: Jim Jarmusch's quietly humorous relationship triptych won the top prize on Saturday. The film about the relationships between siblings, and with their parents, stars Adam Driver, Vicky Krieps and Cate Blanchett.
items.content: Father Mother Sister Brother, at the 2025 Venice Film Festival awards ceremony in Venice, Italy, on Saturday.'/>Jim Jarmusch's quietly humorous relationship triptych won the top prize on Saturday. The film about the relationships between siblings, and with their parents, stars Adam Driver, Vicky Krieps and Cate Blanchett.(Image credit: Scott Garfitt)

items.title: Jim Jarmusch’s 'Father Mother Sister Brother' wins Golden Lion at Venice Film Festival
items.standfirst: US indie director Jim Jarmusch won the Golden Lion award for the best film at the Venice Film Festival on Sunday with family saga "Father Mother Sister Brother". Docudrama "The Voice of Hind Rajab", a harrowing true-life account of the killing of a five-year-old Palestinian girl during the Gaza war, took the runner-up Silver Lion.
items.content: US indie director Jim Jarmusch won the Golden Lion award for the best film at the Venice Film Festival on Sunday with family saga "Father Mother Sister Brother". Docudrama "The Voice of Hind Rajab", a harrowing true-life account of the killing of a five-year-old Palestinian girl during the Gaza war, took the runner-up Silver Lion.

ai_summary: Jim Jarmusch won the Golden Lion at the Venice Film Festival.
His film is titled "Father Mother Sister Brother".
The film is a three-part meditation on family relationships.
The film was a surprise winner of the top prize.
The runner-up was "The Voice of Hind Rajab".

clusters.title: Postal traffic to US sank 80% after Trump administration ended exemption on low-value parcels
clusters.neutral_headline: Postal traffic to US sank 80% after Trump administration ended exemption on low-value parcels

items.title: Postal traffic to US sank 80% after Trump administration ended exemption on low-value parcels
Postal traffic into US plunges by more than 80% after Trump ends exemption
items.standfirst: Dozens of operators have suspended service to the US until a solution is implemented on parcels worth $800 or lessPostal traffic into the United States plunged by more than 80% after the Trump administration ended a tariff exemption for low-cost imports, the United Nations postal agency said Saturday.The Universal Postal Union says it has started rolling out new measures that can help postal operators around the world calculate and collect duties, or taxes, after the US eliminated the so-called “de minimis exemption” for lower-value parcels. Continue reading...
items.content: Dozens of operators have suspended service to the US until a solution is implemented on parcels worth $800 or lessPostal traffic into the United States plunged by more than 80% after the Trump administration ended a tariff exemption for low-cost imports, the United Nations postal agency said Saturday.The Universal Postal Union says it has started rolling out new measures that can help postal operators around the world calculate and collect duties, or taxes, after the US eliminated the so-called “de minimis exemption” for lower-value parcels. Continue reading...

items.title: Eighty-eight postal operators stop sending mail to the US over tariffs
items.standfirst: Some 88 postal operators have either fully or partially stopped sending mail to the US due to President Donald Trump's cancellation of a tax exemption for small packages, the Universal Postal Union said Saturday. In the week since the new rule was introduced, postal traffic to the US fell 81 percent, the group said.

items.standfirst: President Donald Trump threatened on Saturday to unleash his newly rebranded "Department of War" on Chicago, further heightening tensions over his push to deploy troops into Democratic-led US cities. The move seeks to replicate an operation in the US capital Washington, where Trump deployed National Guard troops and boosted numbers of federal agents, sparking a backlash and a fresh protest on Saturday that drew thousands. Story by Charlotte Hughes.

items.title: Drawings reveal Victorian proposal for London’s own Grand Central station
items.standfirst: Perceval Parsons’ plans for station put on sale to mark 200th anniversary of first public passenger railwayThe vaulted arches of New York’s Grand Central station are recognisable even to those who have never taken a train into the Big Apple. But they could very easily have been a sight visible in central London.Shelved 172-year-old architectural drawings by Perceval Parsons show how he envisioned a new London railway connecting the growing number of lines coming into the city to a huge main terminal by the Thames. Continue reading...
items.content: Perceval Parsons’ plans for station put on sale to mark 200th anniversary of first public passenger railwayThe vaulted arches of New York’s Grand Central station are recognisable even to those who have never taken a train into the Big Apple. But they could very easily have been a sight visible in central London.Shelved 172-year-old architectural drawings by Perceval Parsons show how he envisioned a new London railway connecting the growing number of lines coming into the city to a huge main terminal by the Thames. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Stocks in "periphery" European countries are thriving.
These countries were at the heart of the debt crisis.
Equities are performing well in these nations.
The market rally is being led by these stocks.
The trend indicates a recovery in these economies.

clusters.title: Trump hits the links amid economic slowdown concerns
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump hits the links amid economic slowdown concerns

items.title: Trump hits the links amid economic slowdown concerns
items.standfirst: Wall Street took hits on the market after hiring slumped in August. The economy added 22,000 jobs, far below expectations, fueling fresh concerns about a slowdown. Nikole Killion has more details.
items.content: Wall Street took hits on the market after hiring slumped in August. The economy added 22,000 jobs, far below expectations, fueling fresh concerns about a slowdown. Nikole Killion has more details.

items.title: Trump hits the links amid economic slowdown concerns

items.content: Wall Street took hits on the market after hiring slumped in August. The economy added 22,000 jobs, far below expectations, fueling fresh concerns about a slowdown. Nikole Killion has more details.

ai_summary: Wall Street took hits after August hiring slumped.
The economy added 22,000 jobs, below expectations.
This fueled concerns about an economic slowdown.
Trump was playing golf during this time.
Nikole Killion provided more details on the situation.

clusters.title: Pilot who tried to cut off engine midair after taking mushrooms pleads guilty
clusters.neutral_headline: Pilot who tried to cut off engine midair after taking mushrooms pleads guilty

items.title: Pilot who tried to cut off engine midair after taking mushrooms pleads guilty
items.standfirst: The off-duty pilot was sitting in the cockpit of the Alaska Airlines flight when he tried to crash the jet.
items.content: The off-duty pilot was sitting in the cockpit of the Alaska Airlines flight when he tried to crash the jet.

items.title: Former pilot who tried to cut plane engines after taking magic mushrooms pleads guilty
items.standfirst: A former pilot who tried to turn off a plane's engines while riding off-duty on magic mushrooms has pleaded guilty to interfering with a flight crew.
items.content: A former pilot who tried to turn off a plane's engines while riding off-duty on magic mushrooms has pleaded guilty to interfering with a flight crew.

ai_summary: An off-duty pilot tried to crash an Alaska Airlines flight.
He attempted to cut off the engines midair.
The pilot was under the influence of magic mushrooms.
He has pleaded guilty to interfering with a flight crew.
The incident occurred while he was in the cockpit.

clusters.title: Judge rules ending protections for Venezuelan and Haitian migrants is unlawful
clusters.neutral_headline: Judge blocks ending of legal protections for 1m Venezuelans and Haitians in US

items.title: Judge rules ending protections for Venezuelan and Haitian migrants is unlawful
items.standfirst: The decision is in response to the Trump administration's efforts to end temporary protected status (TPS).
items.content: The decision is in response to the Trump administration's efforts to end temporary protected status (TPS).

items.title: Judge blocks ending of legal protections for 1m Venezuelans and Haitians in US
items.standfirst: Homeland security had tried to end temporary protected status granted by the Biden administrationA federal judge on Friday ruled against the Trump administration from ending temporary legal protections that have granted more than 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela the right to live and work in the United States.The ruling by US district judge Edward Chen of San Francisco for the plaintiffs means that 600,000 Venezuelans whose temporary protections expired in April or whose protections were about to expire on 10 September have status to stay and work in the United States. Continue reading...
items.content: Homeland security had tried to end temporary protected status granted by the Biden administrationA federal judge on Friday ruled against the Trump administration from ending temporary legal protections that have granted more than 1 million people from Haiti and Venezuela the right to live and work in the United States.The ruling by US district judge Edward Chen of San Francisco for the plaintiffs means that 600,000 Venezuelans whose temporary protections expired in April or whose protections were about to expire on 10 September have status to stay and work in the United States. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A judge ruled against ending temporary protections.
The protections were for Venezuelans and Haitians.
The Trump administration had tried to end the status.
The ruling affects over one million people.
The judge's decision prevents the protections from ending.
